subs.text: @trekonomics On a certain level, the intellectual impulse may not be that different than what drew me to reading The New Republic at that age.
subs.rawText: @trekonomics On a certain level, the intellectual impulse may not be that different than what drew me to reading The New Republic at that age.

subs.text: @trekonomics But TNR, for all it's faults, wasn't fostering a culture of "debate"; it was still part of the old culture of looking for truth through reporting and analysis. (That, after all, is an era when the @nytimes covered the Supreme Court by running multiple pages from its opinions.)

subs.text: 1/ A question for any datacrunchers among my followers. I have a CSV file with roughly 1000 rows and 100 column. Each row is one response to a hundred questions open ended survey. What is your favorite kosher restaurant? What is your favorite Jewish organization? Etc.
subs.rawText: 1/ A question for any datacrunchers among my followers. I have a CSV file with roughly 1000 rows and 100 column. Each row is one response to a hundred questions open ended survey. What is your favorite kosher restaurant? What is your favorite Jewish organization? Etc.

subs.text: 2/ For each column, I’d like to generate a sorted table of the most popular non-NULL answers, along with how many responses that answer got.
subs.rawText: 2/ For each column, I’d like to generate a sorted table of the most popular non-NULL answers, along with how many responses that answer got.

subs.text: 3/ I would like to separately see a list of all unique entries, so I can massage the data to eliminate misspellings and the like so all entries reading “TA Pizza” in column five can be changed to “Tel Aviv Pizza.”
subs.rawText: 3/ I would like to separately see a list of all unique entries, so I can massage the data to eliminate misspellings and the like so all entries reading “TA Pizza” in column five can be changed to “Tel Aviv Pizza.”

subs.text: 4/ I am rather platform agnostic; I have MS and Libre Office, with their spreadsheets and databases; I’m willing to install a desktop SQL and run Python code; and I’m happy to use a cloud service like Airtable or Tableaux.
subs.rawText: 4/ I am rather platform agnostic; I have MS and Libre Office, with their spreadsheets and databases; I’m willing to install a desktop SQL and run Python code; and I’m happy to use a cloud service like Airtable or Tableaux.

subs.text: 5/ I could code a solution in Perl, but I imagine there are easier solutions out there. So what do you suggest?
subs.rawText: 5/ I could code a solution in Perl, but I imagine there are easier solutions out there. So what do you suggest?

subs.text: @roeiwrites Some related points: 1) There are no consequences for a certain type of pundit in being consistently wrong. Wertheimer is in good company with Gulf War promoters, Brett Stevens, and Bibi Netanyahu.
subs.rawText: @roeiwrites Some related points: 1) There are no consequences for a certain type of pundit in being consistently wrong. Wertheimer is in good company with Gulf War promoters, Brett Stevens, and Bibi Netanyahu.

subs.text: @roeiwrites 2) Wertheimer was a top JTS official when it collapsed, along with Consetvative synagogue affiliation. This was in part because American Jews had dropped old models of Judaism (of which intermarriage is one symptom) but also because of structural and institutional failures.
subs.rawText: @roeiwrites 2) Wertheimer was a top JTS official when it collapsed, along with Consetvative synagogue affiliation. This was in part because American Jews had dropped old models of Judaism (of which intermarriage is one symptom) but also because of structural and institutional failures.

subs.text: @roeiwrites To my knowledge, the only response Wertheimer offered was to lament that Jews no longer felt a sense of “obligation.”
subs.rawText: @roeiwrites To my knowledge, the only response Wertheimer offered was to lament that Jews no longer felt a sense of “obligation.”

subs.text: @roeiwrites At no time did he utilize scholarly models of religion or theology or sociology to figure out what was going on. He stuck with the pre-modern notion that if we just preach harder, people will change their ways.
subs.rawText: @roeiwrites At no time did he utilize scholarly models of religion or theology or sociology to figure out what was going on. He stuck with the pre-modern notion that if we just preach harder, people will change their ways.

subs.text: @roeiwrites (The fact that that model didn’t work for Isaiah or Jeremiah or the Hatam Sofer seems to have escaped him.)
subs.rawText: @roeiwrites (The fact that that model didn’t work for Isaiah or Jeremiah or the Hatam Sofer seems to have escaped him.)

subs.text: @roeiwrites His insistence on seeing American Judaism through traditional categories was a profound epistemological mistake with real communal and institutional consequences.
subs.rawText: @roeiwrites His insistence on seeing American Judaism through traditional categories was a profound epistemological mistake with real communal and institutional consequences.

subs.text: @roeiwrites 3) One “exit interview” question I would like to ask the non and no-longer affiliated is whether the rise of religious extremism in Christian America, Jewish Israel, and the Muslim world had any impact on their view of religious worship.
subs.rawText: @roeiwrites 3) One “exit interview” question I would like to ask the non and no-longer affiliated is whether the rise of religious extremism in Christian America, Jewish Israel, and the Muslim world had any impact on their view of religious worship.

subs.text: @roeiwrites One result of the neoconservative movement’s successful effort to normalize Jews affiliating as Republican, even as the party more and more embraced an extremist religious agenda. I wonder about that effort’s impact on affiliation with Conservative Judaism, which unlike Reform

subs.text: @Stpolishook @prof_dainy It's not a fundraiser. It's a sales platform. Most successful Kickstarter campaign deliver concrete value for the money -- in this case, I assume it's books and signed souvenirs.
subs.rawText: @Stpolishook @prof_dainy It's not a fundraiser. It's a sales platform. Most successful Kickstarter campaign deliver concrete value for the money -- in this case, I assume it's books and signed souvenirs.

subs.text: @Stpolishook @prof_dainy One attraction of Kickstarter for those of us in publishing is the opportunity to take large sums from people who can write four-figure checks without thinking twice.
subs.rawText: @Stpolishook @prof_dainy One attraction of Kickstarter for those of us in publishing is the opportunity to take large sums from people who can write four-figure checks without thinking twice.

subs.text: @Stpolishook @prof_dainy I price my books mindful of people for whom $18 is an expense that requires thought and wouldn't spend $36 for a book. But with a Kickstarter, I can let people willing to pay $1000 to support my projects do so.
subs.rawText: @Stpolishook @prof_dainy I price my books mindful of people for whom $18 is an expense that requires thought and wouldn't spend $36 for a book. But with a Kickstarter, I can let people willing to pay $1000 to support my projects do so.
